<blockquote>
 
<blockquote>
−
"Love of learning is akin to wisdom. To practice with vigor is akin to humanity. To know to be shameful is akin to courage (zhi, ren, yi.. three of [[Mencius|Mengzi]]'s sprouts of virtue)."{{cn}}
+
"Love of learning is akin to wisdom. To practice with vigor is akin to humanity. To know to be shameful is akin to courage (zhi, ren, yi.. three of [[Mencius|Mengzi]]'s sprouts of virtue)."{{cn|date=March 2015}}
 
</blockquote>
 
</blockquote>
    −
Compare this with the Confucian classic ''[[Great Learning]]'', which begins with: "The Way of learning to be great consists in manifesting the clear character, loving the people, and abiding in the highest good." One can clearly see the correlation with the Roman virtue [[prudence]], especially if one interprets "clear character" as "clear conscience". (From [[Chinese Chán|Chan's Sources]] of [[Chinese Philosophy]]).{{cn}}
+
Compare this with the Confucian classic ''[[Great Learning]]'', which begins with: "The Way of learning to be great consists in manifesting the clear character, loving the people, and abiding in the highest good." One can clearly see the correlation with the Roman virtue [[prudence]], especially if one interprets "clear character" as "clear conscience". (From [[Chinese Chán|Chan's Sources]] of [[Chinese Philosophy]]).{{cn|date=March 2015}}
